My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking

My â€œJob Interviewâ€ series is officially award-winning! Iâ€™ve been so busy that I havenâ€™t been able to share that a couple weeks ago I was awarded an Eric Sevareid Award of Merit for one of the first â€œJob Interviewsâ€ I produced. When I first came up with the idea for the series, I had a very loose idea of what I wanted. I knew I wanted to talk to everyday Minnesotans and explore avenues rarely talked about. With the help of Heidi Raschke and Megan Burks, we were able to come up with something simple: Take a news peg from the month, find someone whose work is indirectly/directly related to it, and get them on air. From scoreboard operators, hemp growers and election-ballot designers, Iâ€™ve found some really interesting fields and met some really cool Minnesotans.You can listen to the award-winning interview here:https://lnkd.in/dNZSwtui

The "Unfortunately" phase!The moment I see "Unfortunately..." at the start of an email, I don't even need to read the rest. We all know what follows.As an international student navigating the job market, rejection has become a familiar companion. Some days, I find myself sorting through emails looking only for that one word - "unfortunately" - before moving on to the next message, preserving my mental energy for battles I can win.But here's what I've learned through hundreds of applications and countless rejections:Every "no" is redirecting you to where you belong. Every closed door is guiding you somewhere else. The right opportunity doesn't just need your skills - it needs YOU, with your unique global perspective and cross-cultural insights.The job search feels especially isolating when you're thousands of miles from home, but remember - there's an entire community of internationals walking this same path. Reach out, share stories, offer support.The right opportunity is coming. The right employer will see your international background as the asset it truly is.Keep networking relentlessly. Yes, they say it's easy for locals, but for us internationals... well, we know it's a different game entirely. Every connection counts. Every conversation could open doors that applications alone cannot.Don't lose hope. We've come too far to give up now. Remember all the barriers you've already overcome just to study or work abroad - the visa processes, the cultural adjustments, the distance from family. If you made it through all that, you'll make it through this job search too.Stay strong. Keep applying. This is just a phase, not your permanent reality. We will do this. ğŸ™Œ hashtag#InternationalStudents hashtag#JobSearch hashtag#CareerJourney hashtag#StayResilient hashtag#GlobalTalent hashtag#InternationalNetworking
